title: Nuclear power plants : permanent shutdowns 2005 to 2019
summary: This line chart has an x axis representing Year and a y axis representing Number of shutdowns, with a total of 15 data points. The chart has 6 significant trends.
The longest trend is moderately positive which exists from 2019 to 2016.
Additionally, the next significant trend is moderately positive which exists from 2010 to 2007.
Similarly, the next significant trend is extremely positive which exists from 2016 to 2014.
Additionally, the next significant trend is slightly positive which exists from 2014 to 2012.
Likewise, the next significant trend is extremely positive which exists from 2012 to 2010.
In a similar manner, the next significant trend is slightly negative which exists from 2007 to 2005.
gold: This statistic represents the global number of permanent nuclear reactor shutdowns between 2005 and August 2019 . Following the nuclear accident in Japan in March 2011 , four reactors at Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant were shut down permanently . In total , there were seven permanent shutdowns in 2018 .
